elements.content: A bcu topological three-dimensional Mn(II)-organic framework [Mn22(N3)8(L)12(H2O)26·5H2O]∞ (1) (L = 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarboxylate) based on an unprecedented nanoscale cage has been hydrothermally synthesized. Dominating antiferromagnetic interactions were detected between the MnII ions in 1.
elements.clean_text: A bcu topological three-dimensional Mn(II)-organic framework [Mn22(N3)8(L)12(H2O)26⋅5H2O]∞ (1) (L = 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarboxylate) based on an unprecedented nanoscale cage has been hydrothermally synthesized. Dominating antiferromagnetic interactions were detected between the MnII ions in 1.

elements.content: A new three-dimensional (3D) Mn(II) framework was gained by 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarboxylate ligands with the assistance of azido anions. The 3D structure was based on a nanoscale Mn24L12 cage-like molecular architecture. Competing antiferromagnetic interactions were detected between the metal ions in the complex.
elements.clean_text: A new three-dimensional (3D) Mn(II) framework was gained by 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarboxylate ligands with the assistance of azido anions. The 3D structure was based on a nanoscale Mn24L12 cage-like molecular architecture. Competing antiferromagnetic interactions were detected between the metal ions in the complex.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have drawn considerable attentions owing to their unique architectures and potential applications in some aspects such as gas adsorption and separation, ion exchange, sensing of target molecules, magnetism, nonlinear optics, catalysis, etc. Some MOFs with desirable structures and properties could be designed and controlled during synthesis with some polyatomic metal-containing clusters acting as secondary building units (SBUs). However, in some systems with multiligands or multidentate ligands the construction of a MOF is difficult to anticipate for there are many factors governing the final structure. Though sometimes the architectures of MOFs do not follow a chemist’s blueprint completely, with some fortune, it is serendipitously “designed” in this field.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have drawn considerable attentions owing to their unique architectures and potential applications in some aspects such as gas adsorption and separation, ion exchange, sensing of target molecules, magnetism, nonlinear optics, catalysis, etc. Some MOFs with desirable structures and properties could be designed and controlled during synthesis with some polyatomic metal-containing clusters acting as secondary building units (SBUs). However, in some systems with multiligands or multidentate ligands the construction of a MOF is difficult to anticipate for there are many factors governing the final structure. Though sometimes the architectures of MOFs do not follow a chemist's blueprint completely, with some fortune, it is serendipitously "designed" in this field.

elements.content: As peculiar metal–organic molecular architectures, the constructing of cage molecules is also of great interest for their remarkable structural characteristics and well-defined cavities. And it is an interesting subject to obtain cage-based MOFs which combine these two interesting fields. Assembly of finite single-metal-ion-based molecular building blocks (MBBs), metal–organic cubes (MOC), or metal–organic polyhedra (MOPs) are effective ways in building such complexes. Among the various ligands, multidentate ligand 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate (ImDC) is typical in assembling cage-like complexes and some zeolite-like MOFs based on ImDC have been reported. However, 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarboxylate (L) which has one excessive nitrogen atom than ImDC has never been employed to synthesize cage-based complexes. In this contribution a Mn(II) framework [Mn22(N3)8(L)12(H2O)26·5H2O]∞ (1) based on irregular nanoscale cubic cages was obtained by hydrothermal reaction. The presence of azido anion is essential in forming the structure; otherwise, a 2D complex formulated [C8H12Mn3N6O14·6H2O]∞ was obtained, which was reported by Shi et al. with a little difference in the synthesis process. Thus the azido anions could be considered as structure “directors”. Dominant antiferromagnetic interactions were found between the metal centers.
elements.clean_text: As peculiar metal-organic molecular architectures, the constructing of cage molecules is also of great interest for their remarkable structural characteristics and well-defined cavities. And it is an interesting subject to obtain cage-based MOFs which combine these two interesting fields. Assembly of finite single-metal-ion-based molecular building blocks (MBBs), metal-organic cubes (MOC), or metal-organic polyhedra (MOPs) are effective ways in building such complexes. Among the various ligands, multidentate ligand 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate (ImDC) is typical in assembling cage-like complexes and some zeolite-like MOFs based on ImDC have been reported. However, 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarboxylate (L) which has one excessive nitrogen atom than ImDC has never been employed to synthesize cage-based complexes. In this contribution a Mn(II) framework [Mn22(N3)8(L)12(H2O)26⋅5H2O]∞ (1) based on irregular nanoscale cubic cages was obtained by hydrothermal reaction. The presence of azido anion is essential in forming the structure; otherwise, a 2D complex formulated [C8H12Mn3N6O14⋅6H2O]∞ was obtained, which was reported by Shi et al. with a little difference in the synthesis process. Thus the azido anions could be considered as structure "directors". Dominant antiferromagnetic interactions were found between the metal centers.

elements.content: (a) The asymmetric unit in 1. (b) The linkage of the three types of L ligands in 1. The carbon atoms of the three types of L ligands are marked in different colors: green for L 1 , yellow for L 2 , and sky blue for L 3 .
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The asymmetric unit in 1. (b) The linkage of the three types of L ligands in 1. The carbon atoms of the three types of L ligands are marked in different colors: green for L  1 , yellow for L  2 , and sky blue for L  3 .

elements.content: White crystals of 1 were obtained through the hydrothermal reaction of MnCl2·4H2O, H3 L, NaN3, and water with a mole ratio about 2:1:2:1000 and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, infrared spectrum (), XRPD (), and TGA () analysis. 1 is a 3D coordination network crystallized in the space group P4̅n2. The asymmetric unit contains three L ligands (L 1 , L 2 , and L 3 ), two azido anions, seven coordinated water molecules, six MnII ions, and two lattice water molecules, in which Mn2 and O1W are half occupied while O9W is one-quarter occupied (Figure a,b). The L 1 ligand takes μ5-κO2, O1: κO1,O3: κO3,O4: κO4,N1: κN3,O2 mode chelating to Mn1, Mn2, Mn3, Mn5E, and Mn6F by two carboxylate groups and the nitrogen atoms nearby, leaving the N2 atom uncoordinated. The L 2 ligand coordinates to three MnII ions Mn2, Mn4, and Mn5 using the oxygen atoms of the dicarboxylate groups and the side nitrogen atoms of the triazole ring. The O7 atom also coordinates to Mn1H exhibiting a μ2 bridging mode. The middle nitrogen atom N5 of the triazole coordinates to the Mn3 ion. The L 3 ligand taking the same coordination mode with L 2 links different MnII ions, in which Mn1, Mn4, and Mn5 are chelated by L 3 , Mn3 is coordinated by N8, and Mn3H and Mn4 ions are bridged by O10 in μ2 mode. The azido anions take the monodentate mode coordinating to the MnII ions, which is infrequent in azido carboxylate mixed coordinated systems. Mn1 is coordinated by six oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom from the three L ligands (main bond lengths and angles summarized in ). Although the six coordinated MnII ions are frequent, the MnII ions can also be seven or eight coordinated. Mn2 is chelated by two L 1 and two L 2 ligands giving an eight-coordinated geometry, though the two longer interactions Mn2–O1 and Mn2–O1B are 2.540(6) Å (). Mn3 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from one L 3 , one water molecule, and one chelating L 1 . Mn4 is six coordinated by two terminal azido anions and L 2 , L 3 in chelating mode. Mn5 and Mn6 have the same coordination environment in which Mn5 is chelated by L 1 and L 3 while Mn6 is linked by L 1 and L 2 (,). The water molecules coordinate to Mn5 and Mn6, but the O8W and O9W fill in the space of the lattice.
elements.clean_text: White crystals of 1 were obtained through the hydrothermal reaction of MnCl2⋅4H2O, H3 L, NaN3, and water with a mole ratio about 2:1:2:1000 and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, infrared spectrum (), XRPD (), and TGA () analysis. 1 is a 3D coordination network crystallized in the space group P4̅n2. The asymmetric unit contains three L ligands (L  1 , L  2 , and L  3 ), two azido anions, seven coordinated water molecules, six MnII ions, and two lattice water molecules, in which Mn2 and O1W are half occupied while O9W is one-quarter occupied (Figure a,b). The L  1  ligand takes μ5-κO2, O1: κO1,O3: κO3,O4: κO4,N1: κN3,O2 mode chelating to Mn1, Mn2, Mn3, Mn5E, and Mn6F by two carboxylate groups and the nitrogen atoms nearby, leaving the N2 atom uncoordinated. The L  2  ligand coordinates to three MnII ions Mn2, Mn4, and Mn5 using the oxygen atoms of the dicarboxylate groups and the side nitrogen atoms of the triazole ring. The O7 atom also coordinates to Mn1H exhibiting a μ2 bridging mode. The middle nitrogen atom N5 of the triazole coordinates to the Mn3 ion. The L  3  ligand taking the same coordination mode with L  2  links different MnII ions, in which Mn1, Mn4, and Mn5 are chelated by L  3 , Mn3 is coordinated by N8, and Mn3H and Mn4 ions are bridged by O10 in μ2 mode. The azido anions take the monodentate mode coordinating to the MnII ions, which is infrequent in azido carboxylate mixed coordinated systems. Mn1 is coordinated by six oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom from the three L ligands (main bond lengths and angles summarized in ). Although the six coordinated MnII ions are frequent, the MnII ions can also be seven or eight coordinated. Mn2 is chelated by two L  1  and two L  2  ligands giving an eight-coordinated geometry, though the two longer interactions Mn2-O1 and Mn2-O1B are 2.540(6) Å (). Mn3 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from one L  3 , one water molecule, and one chelating L  1 . Mn4 is six coordinated by two terminal azido anions and L  2 , L  3  in chelating mode. Mn5 and Mn6 have the same coordination environment in which Mn5 is chelated by L  1  and L  3  while Mn6 is linked by L  1  and L  2  (,). The water molecules coordinate to Mn5 and Mn6, but the O8W and O9W fill in the space of the lattice.

elements.content: (a) The linkage of the plane formed by L 2 , L 3 , and Mn3–Mn6. (b, c) The view of the sandglass-like core in different directions. Azido anions and water in the core are shown in space filling mode. (d) The 1D chain formed by L 1 , O1W, Mn1, and Mn2. (e) The 3D framework of 1. (f) The 4,8-connected nets of 1. (g) The sketch of the Mn24 L 12 cage in the 4,8-connected nets. (h) The Mn24 L 12 cage of 1. (i) The bcu topology of 1 as the Mn22 cage simplified as eight-connected nodes.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) The linkage of the plane formed by L  2 , L  3 , and Mn3-Mn6. (b, c) The view of the sandglass-like core in different directions. Azido anions and water in the core are shown in space filling mode. (d) The 1D chain formed by L  1 , O1W, Mn1, and Mn2. (e) The 3D framework of 1. (f) The 4,8-connected nets of 1. (g) The sketch of the Mn24 L 12 cage in the 4,8-connected nets. (h) The Mn24 L 12 cage of 1. (i) The bcu topology of 1 as the Mn22 cage simplified as eight-connected nodes.

elements.content: The structure of 1 is considerably complicated. Analyzing the 3D structure, it is not difficult to find that the basic unit is Mn24 L 12 cage-like unit one. The chelating coordinated mode of the L ligands and the coordination of the three nitrogen atoms of the triazole ring in L 2 and L 3 are very important in constructing the plane structure which is vital in forming a cage. Thus, in order to understand the formation of the complex, the structure of 1 was predigested into three parts (Figure ). The cores of the cage were constructed by the ligands L 2 , L 3 , Mn3Mn4, Mn5, and Mn6. The L 2 and L 3 link Mn3, Mn4, Mn5, and Mn6 giving a plane, and the neighbor planes were connected through the coordination bond formed by Mn3 and O10 (Figure a). Four such planes link in turn forming a sandglass-like Mn16L8 molecule architecture (Figure b,c) with four azido anions, O9W filling in and four azido anions surrounding. The other two parts of the structure form a chain by using Mn1 ions, L 1 ligands, O1W, and Mn2 with a ratio of 2:2:1:1 (Figure d). It is worth mentioning that each L 1 –Mn1–O1W–Mn1–L 1 segment and Mn2 ion could be considered as four connected nodes, and the core could be viewed as an eight-connected node (). In that way the whole framework could be comprehended as a 4,8-connected nbo-x-d/Im3̅m → I4/mmm net with point notation {32;62;72}4{34;612;712} (Figure f). The 3D structure of the complex (Figure e) has a basic Mn24 L 12 cage unit, which contains a Mn16 L 8 core, four L1–Mn1–O1W segments, and four Mn2 ions of about one nanometer in length, width, and height (Figure h). If we halve the four-connected node and ascribe every half to the eight-connected core, the whole framework could be viewed as a bcu net in which the Mn24 L 12 cage is viewed as a node and connects to eight neighbors though the linkage of Mn2 and L 1 –Mn1–O1W segments (Figures g and ). The cage contains 24 MnII ions, while in the bcu topology every node contains Mn22 L 12 units, because the Mn2 ion is only half contained in predigesting (Figure i).
elements.clean_text: The structure of 1 is considerably complicated. Analyzing the 3D structure, it is not difficult to find that the basic unit is Mn24 L 12 cage-like unit one. The chelating coordinated mode of the L ligands and the coordination of the three nitrogen atoms of the triazole ring in L  2  and L  3  are very important in constructing the plane structure which is vital in forming a cage. Thus, in order to understand the formation of the complex, the structure of 1 was predigested into three parts (Figure ). The cores of the cage were constructed by the ligands L  2 , L  3 , Mn3Mn4, Mn5, and Mn6. The L  2  and L  3  link Mn3, Mn4, Mn5, and Mn6 giving a plane, and the neighbor planes were connected through the coordination bond formed by Mn3 and O10 (Figure a). Four such planes link in turn forming a sandglass-like Mn16L8 molecule architecture (Figure b,c) with four azido anions, O9W filling in and four azido anions surrounding. The other two parts of the structure form a chain by using Mn1 ions, L  1  ligands, O1W, and Mn2 with a ratio of 2:2:1:1 (Figure d). It is worth mentioning that each L  1 -Mn1-O1W-Mn1-L  1  segment and Mn2 ion could be considered as four connected nodes, and the core could be viewed as an eight-connected node (). In that way the whole framework could be comprehended as a 4,8-connected nbo-x-d/Im3̅m → I4/mmm net with point notation {32;62;72}4{34;612;712} (Figure f). The 3D structure of the complex (Figure e) has a basic Mn24 L 12 cage unit, which contains a Mn16 L 8 core, four L1-Mn1-O1W segments, and four Mn2 ions of about one nanometer in length, width, and height (Figure h). If we halve the four-connected node and ascribe every half to the eight-connected core, the whole framework could be viewed as a bcu net in which the Mn24 L 12 cage is viewed as a node and connects to eight neighbors though the linkage of Mn2 and L  1 -Mn1-O1W segments (Figures g and ). The cage contains 24 MnII ions, while in the bcu topology every node contains Mn22 L 12 units, because the Mn2 ion is only half contained in predigesting (Figure i).

elements.content: The magnetization vs field plot at 2.0 K of 1. Insets: the χm T vs T (blue) and χm vs T plots (red) of 1.
elements.clean_text: 3  The magnetization vs field plot at 2.0 K of 1. Insets: the χm T vs T (blue) and χm vs T plots (red) of 1.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured in the 2–300 K temperature range under 1 kOe and shown as χm T vs T plots in Figure insets. The χm T value at 300 K is 3.64 cm3 K mol–1, which is lower than the value 4.4 cm3 mol–1 K for one isolated octahedral MnII ion with g = 2.0, suggesting the existence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the MnII ions. As cooling, the χm T product decreases to the minimum value of 0.264 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, which suggests dominating antiferromagnetic coupling between the MnII ions as well. The χm –1 vs T plots above 50 K following the Curie–Weiss law give C = 4.09 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −33.15 K (). The negative value of θ also indicates the overall antiferromagnetic coupling between the MnII ions. The magnetization curve at 2.0 K, as shown in Figure , does not follow the Brillouin curve but increases linearly with field, which agrees with the antiferromagnetic interactions in 1. However, there is no pack in the χm vs T curve and the extreme of dχ m T/dT vs T curve is lower than 2 K, all of which indicate the absence of long-range antiferromagnetic order above 2 K (). In 1, the L ligands transfer antiferromagnetic coupling and offer several triangular super-exchange ways between the MnII ions leading to strong spin competition in 1 with large frustration parameter f (f = |θ|/T N) 16.58 (33.15/2.0).
elements.clean_text: The magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured in the 2-300 K temperature range under 1 kOe and shown as χm T vs T plots in Figure  insets. The χm T value at 300 K is 3.64 cm3 K mol-1, which is lower than the value 4.4 cm3 mol-1 K for one isolated octahedral MnII ion with g = 2.0, suggesting the existence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the MnII ions. As cooling, the χm T product decreases to the minimum value of 0.264 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, which suggests dominating antiferromagnetic coupling between the MnII ions as well. The χm -1 vs T plots above 50 K following the Curie-Weiss law give C = 4.09 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -33.15 K (). The negative value of θ also indicates the overall antiferromagnetic coupling between the MnII ions. The magnetization curve at 2.0 K, as shown in Figure , does not follow the Brillouin curve but increases linearly with field, which agrees with the antiferromagnetic interactions in 1. However, there is no pack in the χm vs T curve and the extreme of dχ m T/dT vs T curve is lower than 2 K, all of which indicate the absence of long-range antiferromagnetic order above 2 K (). In 1, the L ligands transfer antiferromagnetic coupling and offer several triangular super-exchange ways between the MnII ions leading to strong spin competition in 1 with large frustration parameter f (f = |θ|/T N) 16.58 (33.15/2.0).

elements.content: In summary, with the assistance of the azido anions nanoscale cage-based MnII framework is formed by the 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarboxylate ligand through hydrothermal reaction. Although the connections of the metal ions and ligands are extraordinary, by analyzing the structure, the complex shows an eight-connected cage-based framework. Magnetic investigation reveals that competing antiferromagnetic interactions were detected between the metal ions in the complex.
elements.clean_text: In summary, with the assistance of the azido anions nanoscale cage-based MnII framework is formed by the 1,2,3-triazole-4,5-dicarboxylate ligand through hydrothermal reaction. Although the connections of the metal ions and ligands are extraordinary, by analyzing the structure, the complex shows an eight-connected cage-based framework. Magnetic investigation reveals that competing antiferromagnetic interactions were detected between the metal ions in the complex.

elements.content:
X-ray crystallographic data for complex 1 in CIF format, Table S1 and Figure S1–S7. These materials are available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References

Synthesis of 1: A mixture of MnCl2·4H2O (1.5 mmol), H3 L (0.75 mmol), and NaN3 (1.5 mmol) in 15 mL of water was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated at 140 °C for 2 days under autogenous pressure, and then cooled to room temperature. Whiter crystals of 1 were harvested in a yield of ca. 25% based on metal. Element analysis (%): Calcd. for C48H62Mn22N60O79 (3952.26): C 14.59, H 1.58, N 21.26; found: C 14.21, H 1.76, N 21.63.

elements.content: Crystal data for 1, C48H62Mn22N60O79: M = 3952.26, Tetragonal, P4̅n2, a = 20.019(3), b = 20.019(3), c = 18.861(4) Å, V = 7558(2) Å3, Z = 2, D c = 1.737 Mg/m3, μ = 1.873 mm–1, [R(int) = 0.1066 ], a total of 58212 reflections were collected, of which 5791 reflections as observed (I > 2σ(I)), final R 1 = 0.0759, wR 1 = 0.1683 (I > 2σ(I)).

cln_elements.content:
The magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured in the 2–300 K temperature range under 1 kOe and shown as χm T vs T plots in Figure insets. The χm T value at 300 K is 3.64 cm3 K mol–1, which is lower than the value 4.4 cm3 mol–1 K for one isolated octahedral MnII ion with g = 2.0, suggesting the existence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the MnII ions. As cooling, the χm T product decreases to the minimum value of 0.264 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, which suggests dominating antiferromagnetic coupling between the MnII ions as well. The χm –1 vs T plots above 50 K following the Curie–Weiss law give C = 4.09 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −33.15 K (). The negative value of θ also indicates the overall antiferromagnetic coupling between the MnII ions. The magnetization curve at 2.0 K, as shown in Figure , does not follow the Brillouin curve but increases linearly with field, which agrees with the antiferromagnetic interactions in 1. However, there is no pack in the χm vs T curve and the extreme of dχ m T/dT vs T curve is lower than 2 K, all of which indicate the absence of long-range antiferromagnetic order above 2 K (). In 1, the L ligands transfer antiferromagnetic coupling and offer several triangular super-exchange ways between the MnII ions leading to strong spin competition in 1 with large frustration parameter f (f = |θ|/T N) 16.58 (33.15/2.0).

(g) The sketch of the Mn24 L 12 cage in the 4,8-connected nets. (h) The Mn24 L 12 cage of 1. (i) The bcu topology of 1 as the Mn22 cage simplified as eight-connected nodes.

metadata.title:
Azido-Directed Formation
of An Unprecedented Mn(II)-Organic
Framework with Nanoscale Cubic Cage Units
